article.title: Root Skewing-Associated Genes Impact the Spaceflight Response of Arabidopsis thaliana
funding: NASA SLPSRA grants NNX12AN69G and NNX14AT24G
article.abstract: The observation that plant roots skew in microgravity recently refuted the long-held conviction that skewing was a gravity-dependent phenomenon.

sections.introduction: Spaceflight studies offer unique insights into plant biological processes, and enable the exploration of the relationships between root morphology, gene expression and the physiological adaptation to spaceflight.
sections.methods: Arabidopsis thaliana wild ecotype Columbia (Col-0, CS70000) seed stock, and T-DNA insertion lines for the spr1 (CS6547 – Col-0 background) and sku5 (CS16268 – WS background), were acquired from the Arabidopsis Biological Resource Center (ABRC) (arabidopsis.org; Lamesch et al., 2011).
sections.results: APEX-03 seedling growth in occurred in the Veggie hardware on the ISS (Figure 1A).
sections.discussion: The discovery that root skewing was not gravity-dependent, and prevalent in both light-grown and dark-grown plants in spaceflight habitats (Millar et al., 2011; Paul et al., 2012a; Nakashima et al., 2014), invited questions about the underlying mechanisms of this behavior in the microgravity environment and the relationship between those mechanisms and physiological adaptation to spaceflight.
